results.name: Sally M Nangala Mulda

roles_in_work.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls

results.biography: Two Girls will tell the intertwining stories of Sally and Marlene, both renowned Town Camp artists, who shared their childhood at the Amoonguna Settlement in the Northern Territory and remained in contact to the present day. Their work will chronicle the artists’ successes and struggles, showcasing the reality of life for Indigenous Australians in Central Australia, ultimately celebrating their enduring friendship.

results.name: Left Of Elephant Sound

roles_in_work.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls

results.biography:
Left Of Elephant Sound, the home of Jeremy (Jez) Conlon, a professional location sound recordist, sound engineer, music producer, arranger, and composer based in Mparntwe (Alice Springs – Central Australia).

We offer a range of services including location sound recording, music mastering, music mixing, ADR/voiceover, and location music recording.

With years of experience in the music and sound engineering industry, Jez has worked with world-class artists, including Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu (at Avatar Studio, formerly Power Station NYC), Tom E Lewis, Toni Childs, Ross Hannaford, and has recorded in unique and non-traditional places, such as old churches, live performance gigs, and backyard verandahs.

Mparntwe offers unique recording spaces, including the legendary CAAMA Music Studio, Red House Studio, and White Gums Octagonal Room.

At Left Of Elephant Sound, we believe feeling comfortable and relaxed is paramount to getting a good performance, which is why we strive to utilise vibrant and creatively inspiring places to capture unique sound.

[Source: Left Of Elephant Sound website https://www.leftofelephantsound.com.au/ Last accessed 20230503]

results.name: Courtney Collins

roles_in_work.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls

results.biography:
I am a writer and producer.

In 2017, I started Ngukurr Story Projects to support local First Nations storytellers in Ngukurr, NT, to 'tell the stories in traditional and endangered languages.

My first novel, The Burial (Allen & Unwin), was published in ten countries and shortlisted for numerous prizes, including the Nita B Kibble Literary Award, NSW Premier's Literary Awards for New Writing and the Stella Prize. It is currently being adapted as a feature film directed by Jasmin Tarasin.

I hold a Masters of Creative Writing (University of Melbourne) and I have taught creative writing in Australia and overseas, most recently at Batchelor Institute. I am an Asialink Fellow and a Sidney Myer Fellow. In 2019 I was part of the Australian Screen Producers' Association's 'Ones to Watch Program'.

I am currently a PhD candidate, researching the topic 'How To Work Against Whiteness in Creative Literary Production.

[Source: Linked In https://www.linkedin.com/in/courtneycollinswriter/?trk=people-guest_people_search-card&originalSubdomain=au
Last accessed: 20230503]
